title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement [INSERT CONTACT METHOD]. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/ code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https:// www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to additive
text: outlines propose change additive. detailed info contributing , tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide.

title: Contributing to additive
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to additive
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Contributing to additive
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("", fork = TRUE). Install development dependences devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to additive
text: New R code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles. Please don’t restyle code nothing PR. New C/C++ code follow Google style guide. can use clang-format apply styles. Please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, build documentation package. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to additive
text: Please note additive project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Getting help with additive
text: Start making minimal reproducible example using reprex package. haven’t heard used reprex , ’re treat! Seriously, reprex make R-question-asking endeavors easier (pretty insane ROI five ten minutes ’ll take learn ’s ). additional reprex pointers, check Get help! section tidyverse site.

title: Getting help with additive
text: Armed reprex, next step figure ask. ’s question: start community.rstudio.com, /StackOverflow. people answer questions. ’s bug: ’re right place, file issue. ’re sure: let community help figure ! problem bug feature request, can easily return report . opening new issue, sure search issues pull requests make sure bug hasn’t reported /already fixed development version. default, search pre-populated :issue :open. can edit qualifiers (e.g. :pr, :closed) needed. example, ’d simply remove :open search issues repo, open closed.

title: Getting help with additive
text: efficient possible, development R packages tends bursty, shouldn’t worry don’t get immediate response. Typically don’t look repo sufficient quantity issues accumulates, ’s burst intense activity focus efforts. makes development efficient avoids expensive context switching problems, cost taking longer get back . process makes good reprex particularly important might multiple months initial report start working . can’t reproduce bug, can’t fix !

title: Bug Reporting
text: Provide clear concise description problem including warning error messages.

title: Bug Reporting
text: Provide clean R script demonstrating issue necessary data files. Please include minimal reproducible example (AKA reprex). ’ve never heard reprex , start reading https://www.tidyverse.org/help/#reprex.

title: Bug Reporting
text: Provide following information: OS Type: [e.g., Linux, macOS, Windows] OS Version: [e.g., macOS 11.3, Windows 10, Ubuntu 20.04] R Version: [e.g., 4.0, 4.1, 4.2] Version: [e.g., 0.0.3 development] Source: [e.g., binary source code] Repository: [e.g., CRAN, Bioconductor, GitHub, ]

title: Bindings for Additive TidyModels
text: additive supports Generalized Additive Models (GAM) using mgcv parsnip/tidymodels.

title: Bindings for Additive TidyModels
text: stable version additive can installed CRAN using: development version additive can installed GitHub using:

title: Bindings for Additive TidyModels
text: details, get started additive.
code: library(additive)  set.seed(2020) dat <- gamSim(1, n = 400, dist = "normal", scale = 2)  additive_mod <-   additive() %>%   set_engine("mgcv") %>%   fit(     y ~ s(x0) + s(x1) + s(x2) + s(x3),     data = dat   )  summary(additive_mod$fit)

title: Bindings for Additive TidyModels
text: cite additive publications, please use: Hamada S. Badr (2021): additive: Bindings Additive TidyModels, Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN). URL: https://hsbadr.github.io/additive/.

title: Bindings for Additive TidyModels
text: project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms. questions discussions tidymodels packages, modeling, machine learning, please post RStudio Community. think encountered bug, please submit issue. Either way, learn create share reprex (minimal, reproducible example), clearly communicate code. Check details contributing guidelines tidymodels packages get help.

what: General Interface for Additive TidyModels — additive
title: General Interface for Additive TidyModels — additive

title: General Interface for Additive TidyModels — additive
code: additive(   mode = "regression",   engine = "mgcv",   fitfunc = NULL,   formula.override = NULL,   family = NULL,   method = NULL,   optimizer = NULL,   control = NULL,   scale = NULL,   gamma = NULL,   knots = NULL,   sp = NULL,   min.sp = NULL,   paraPen = NULL,   chunk.size = NULL,   rho = NULL,   AR.start = NULL,   H = NULL,   G = NULL,   offset = NULL,   weights = NULL,   subset = NULL,   start = NULL,   etastart = NULL,   mustart = NULL,   drop.intercept = NULL,   drop.unused.levels = NULL,   cluster = NULL,   nthreads = NULL,   gc.level = NULL,   use.chol = NULL,   samfrac = NULL,   coef = NULL,   discrete = NULL,   select = NULL,   fit = NULL )  # S3 method for additive update(   object,   parameters = NULL,   fitfunc = NULL,   formula.override = NULL,   family = NULL,   method = NULL,   optimizer = NULL,   control = NULL,   scale = NULL,   gamma = NULL,   knots = NULL,   sp = NULL,   min.sp = NULL,   paraPen = NULL,   chunk.size = NULL,   rho = NULL,   AR.start = NULL,   H = NULL,   G = NULL,   offset = NULL,   weights = NULL,   subset = NULL,   start = NULL,   etastart = NULL,   mustart = NULL,   drop.intercept = NULL,   drop.unused.levels = NULL,   cluster = NULL,   nthreads = NULL,   gc.level = NULL,   use.chol = NULL,   samfrac = NULL,   coef = NULL,   discrete = NULL,   select = NULL,   fit = NULL,   fresh = FALSE,   ... )  additive_fit(formula, data, ...)

title: General Interface for Additive TidyModels — additive
text: mode single character string prediction outcome mode. Possible values model "unknown", "regression", "classification". engine single character string specifying computational engine use fitting. Possible engines listed . default model "mgcv". fitfunc named character vector describes call function fitting generalized additive model. defaults c(pkg = "mgcv", fun = "gam") (gam). fitfunc elements pkg fun. former optional recommended latter required. example, c(pkg = "mgcv", fun = "bam") used invoke bam big data. user-specified function also accepted provided fully compatible gam. formula.override Overrides formula; details see formula.gam. family family object specifying distribution link use fitting etc (see glm family). See  family.mgcv full list available, goes well beyond exponential family. Note quasi families actually result use extended quasi-likelihood  method set RE/ML method (McCullagh Nelder, 1989, 9.6). method smoothing parameter estimation method. "GCV.Cp" use GCV unknown scale parameter Mallows' Cp/UBRE/AIC known scale. "GACV.Cp" equivalent, using GACV place GCV. "REML"  REML estimation, including unknown scale, "P-REML" REML estimation, using Pearson estimate  scale. "ML" "P-ML" similar, using maximum likelihood place REML. Beyond  exponential family "REML" default, option "ML". optimizer array specifying numerical optimization method use optimize smoothing  parameter estimation criterion (given method). "perf" (deprecated) performance iteration. "outer"  stable direct approach. "outer" can use several alternative optimizers, specified  second element optimizer: "newton" (default), "bfgs", "optim", "nlm"  "nlm.fd" (latter based entirely finite differenced derivatives slow). "efs" extended Fellner Schall method Wood Fasiolo (2017). control list fit control parameters replace defaults returned  gam.control. Values set assume default values. scale positive taken known scale parameter. Negative signals  scale parameter unknown. 0 signals scale parameter 1  Poisson binomial unknown otherwise.  Note (RE)ML methods can work scale parameter 1 Poisson binomial cases. gamma Increase beyond 1 produce smoother models. gamma multiplies effective degrees freedom GCV UBRE/AIC. coden/gamma can viewed effective sample size GCV score, also enables used REML/ML. Ignored P-RE/ML efs optimizer. knots optional list containing user specified knot values used basis construction.  bases user simply supplies knots used, must match k value supplied (note number knots always just k).  See tprs happens "tp"/"ts" case.  Different terms can use different numbers knots, unless share covariate. sp vector smoothing parameters can provided .  Smoothing parameters must supplied order smooth terms appear model  formula. Negative elements indicate parameter estimated, hence mixture  fixed estimated parameters possible. smooths share smoothing parameters length(sp)  must correspond number underlying smoothing parameters. min.sp Lower bounds can supplied smoothing parameters. Note option used smoothing parameters full.sp,  returned object, need added supplied get   smoothing parameters actually multiplying penalties. length(min.sp)  always total number penalties (may longer sp, smooths share smoothing parameters). paraPen optional list specifying penalties applied parametric model terms.  gam.models explains . chunk.size model matrix created chunks size, rather ever formed whole.  Reset 4*p chunk.size < 4*p p number coefficients. rho AR1 error model can used residuals (based dataframe order), Gaussian-identity             link models. AR1 correlation parameter. Standardized residuals (approximately             uncorrelated correct model) returned             std.rsd non zero. Also usable models discrete=TRUE, case AR model            applied working residuals corresponds GEE approximation. AR.start logical variable length data, TRUE first observation independent section AR1 correlation. first observation data frame need . NULL  breaks AR1 correlaion. H user supplied fixed quadratic penalty parameters  GAM can supplied, coefficient matrix. common use term  add ridge penalty parameters GAM circumstances model close un-identifiable scale linear predictor, perfectly well defined response scale. G Usually NULL, may contain object returned previous call gam  fit=FALSE, case arguments ignored except sp, gamma, ., scale, control, method optimizer fit. offset Can used supply model offset use fitting. Note offset always completely ignored predicting, unlike offset  included formula (used conform behaviour lm glm). weights prior weights contribution data log likelihood. Note weight 2, example,                  equivalent made exactly observation twice. want re-weight contributions                  datum without changing overall magnitude log likelihood, normalize weights                 (e.g. weights <- weights/mean(weights)). subset optional vector specifying subset observations           used fitting process. start Initial values model coefficients. etastart Initial values linear predictor. mustart Initial values expected response. drop.intercept Set TRUE force model really constant parametric model part, even factor variables present. Can vector formula list. drop.unused.levels default unused levels dropped factors fitting. smooths  involving factor variables might want turn . know . cluster bam can compute computationally dominant QR decomposition parallel using parLapply parallel package, supplied cluster (cluster can cores  single machine). See details example code. nthreads Number threads use non-cluster computation (e.g. combining results cluster nodes). NA set max(1,length(cluster)). See details. gc.level keep memory footprint , can help call garbage collector often, takes  substatial amount time. Setting zero means garbage collection happens R decides . Setting 2 gives frequent garbage collection. 1 . much problem used . use.chol default bam uses stable QR update approach obtaining QR decomposition model matrix. well conditioned models alternative accumulates crossproduct model matrix finds Choleski decomposition, end. somewhat efficient, computationally. samfrac large sample size Generalized additive models number iterations needed model fit can  reduced first fitting model random sample data, using results supply starting values. initial fit run sloppy convergence tolerances, typically low cost. samfrac sampling fraction use. 0.1 often reasonable. coef initial values model coefficients discrete experimental option setting models use discrete methods employed bam. modify. select TRUE gam can add extra penalty term  can penalized zero.  means smoothing parameter estimation  part fitting can completely remove terms model. corresponding  smoothing parameter estimated zero extra penalty effect. Use gamma increase level penalization. fit argument TRUE gam sets model fits , FALSE model set object G containing required fit returned returned. See argument G. object Generalized Additive Model (GAM) specification. parameters 1-row tibble named list main parameters update. individual arguments used, supersede values parameters. Also, using engine arguments object result error. fresh logical whether arguments modified -place replaced wholesale. ... arguments passed internal functions. formula GAM formula, list formulae (see formula.gam also gam.models).  exactly like formula GLM except smooth terms, s, te, ti  t2, can added right hand side specify linear predictor depends smooth functions predictors (linear functionals ). data data frame list containing model response variable  covariates required formula. default variables taken  environment(formula): typically environment  gam called.

title: General Interface for Additive TidyModels — additive
text: Engines may pre-set default arguments executing model fit call. type model, template fit calls :

title: General Interface for Additive TidyModels — additive
code: additive() #> Generalized Additive Model (GAM) Specification (regression) #>  #> Computational engine: mgcv  #>   show_model_info("additive") #> Information for `additive` #>  modes: unknown, classification, regression  #>  #>  engines:  #>    classification: mgcv #>    regression:     mgcv #>  #>  arguments:  #>    mgcv:  #>       fitfunc            --> fitfunc #>       formula.override   --> formula.override #>       family             --> family #>       method             --> method #>       optimizer          --> optimizer #>       control            --> control #>       scale              --> scale #>       gamma              --> gamma #>       knots              --> knots #>       sp                 --> sp #>       min.sp             --> min.sp #>       paraPen            --> paraPen #>       chunk.size         --> chunk.size #>       rho                --> rho #>       AR.start           --> AR.start #>       H                  --> H #>       G                  --> G #>       offset             --> offset #>       weights            --> weights #>       subset             --> subset #>       start              --> start #>       etastart           --> etastart #>       mustart            --> mustart #>       drop.intercept     --> drop.intercept #>       drop.unused.levels --> drop.unused.levels #>       cluster            --> cluster #>       nthreads           --> nthreads #>       gc.level           --> gc.level #>       use.chol           --> use.chol #>       samfrac            --> samfrac #>       coef               --> coef #>       discrete           --> discrete #>       select             --> select #>       fit                --> fit #>  #>  fit modules: #>  engine           mode #>    mgcv classification #>    mgcv     regression #>  #>  prediction modules: #>              mode engine                              methods #>    classification   mgcv class, conf_int, pred_int, prob, raw #>        regression   mgcv     conf_int, numeric, pred_int, raw #>   additive(mode = "classification") #> Generalized Additive Model (GAM) Specification (classification) #>  #> Computational engine: mgcv  #>  additive(mode = "regression") #> Generalized Additive Model (GAM) Specification (regression) #>  #> Computational engine: mgcv  #>   set.seed(2020) dat <- gamSim(1, n = 400, dist = "normal", scale = 2) #> Gu & Wahba 4 term additive model  additive_mod <-   additive() %>%   set_engine("mgcv") %>%   fit(     y ~ s(x0) + s(x1) + s(x2) + s(x3),     data = dat   )  summary(additive_mod$fit) #>  #> Family: gaussian  #> Link function: identity  #>  #> Formula: #> y ~ s(x0) + s(x1) + s(x2) + s(x3) #>  #> Parametric coefficients: #>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept)  7.89798    0.09692   81.49   <2e-16 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Approximate significance of smooth terms: #>         edf Ref.df      F p-value     #> s(x0) 5.785  6.916  7.744  <2e-16 *** #> s(x1) 2.959  3.680 78.625  <2e-16 *** #> s(x2) 8.315  8.866 86.414  <2e-16 *** #> s(x3) 2.419  3.015  1.016   0.388     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> R-sq.(adj) =   0.75   Deviance explained = 76.2% #> GCV = 3.9601  Scale est. = 3.7574    n = 400  model <- additive(select = FALSE) model #> Generalized Additive Model (GAM) Specification (regression) #>  #> Main Arguments: #>   select = FALSE #>  #> Computational engine: mgcv  #>  update(model, select = TRUE) #> Generalized Additive Model (GAM) Specification (regression) #>  #> Main Arguments: #>   select = TRUE #>  #> Computational engine: mgcv  #>  update(model, select = TRUE, fresh = TRUE) #> Generalized Additive Model (GAM) Specification (regression) #>  #> Main Arguments: #>   select = TRUE #>  #> Computational engine: mgcv  #>
